tn.text: AT: "an unstoppable destruction" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This is another word for Babylon.
To scatter is to separate and send in different directions.
The phrase "day of" is a Hebrew idiom for "when." AT: "when she is destroyed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Do not let the archers bend their bows
tn.text: "Do not allow the archers time to prepare to shoot"
AT: "Babylon was a strong nation used for judgment" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
AT: "unable to think clearly"
This is a loud, long cry of sadness.

tn.ref: For her guilt reaches up to the heavens; it is piled up to the clouds
tn.text: AT: "Babylon is so very guilty" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
Yahweh had punished the Israelites for their sins, but now has let them return to him.
This means people who live in a particular place.

tn.ref: live by many streams of water
tn.text: "are happy and wealthy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"Your lives will be ended quickly. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"with a large number of soldiers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
This is a shout that a soldier makes in battle.

tn.ref: When he thunders, there is the roar of waters in the heavens
tn.text: These phrases compare the voice of Yahweh to the loud sound made by thunder and rain. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
A storehouse is a place where things are kept for future use.

tn.ref: Every man becomes like an animal without knowledge
tn.text: This shows Jeremiah's feeling that people who believe in idols are very stupid! (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
AT: "lies in order to cheat"
AT: "The Babylonian army"
AT: "The Babylonian Army."
AT: "You Babylonians will certainly see" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
AT: "what Yahweh has solemnly said"

Yahweh talks to Babylon as if it were a mountain which he could address as a person. Since mountains were sometimes the homes of bandits, it is possible that Jeremiah had this idea in mind here. See UDB. AT: "strong nation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This refers to all the people Babylon has attacked.
A cliff is the steep side of a mountain or hill.
Large flag for the soldiers to follow in battle. AT: "flag"
AT: "Babylon"
These are names of nations or people groups. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: bring up horses like swarming locusts
tn.text: Yahweh compares a great number of horses to a swarm of locusts. AT: "bring many horses with soldiers quickly." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
Yahweh promises such great upheaval that the whole nation will tremble. The "land" represents the people of Babylon living there. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Babylon will be in great distress.
"The enemies overcame the whole city." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: the fords over the river are seized
tn.text: The enemies take control of all the crossing places of the river. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
A ford is a shallow part of a river where people can walk across easily.
AT: "Unable to think clearly"
"Daughter of Babylon" is another name for the residents of Babylon. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Yahweh compares threshing to the time of great pressure upon Babylon. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: time of harvest will come to her
tn.text: The harvest is the result of the actions that the people did before. The result of Babylon's sins will come. AT: "Babylon will be punished." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: He has drained me dry and has made me into an empty pot
tn.text: Babylon has taken everything from Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Jerusalem compares its destruction to being swallowed. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This compares Babylon to a dragon. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: He filled his stomach with my good food.
tn.text: This states in another way the previous idea that Babylon has taken everything from Israel. "Food" represents all the good things there before. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
What Babylon did not like after taking everything he threw away like rinsing out old food out of a cooking pot. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
AT: "People who live in Chaldea."
This begins Yahweh's reply to Jerusalem's request in verses 34 and 35.
This refers to the buildings becoming piles of trash.
AT: "a home for wild dogs"
Something that terrifies anybody looking at it. AT: "a terrible place to live"
This is a sound that shows strong disapproval.
This is a loud sound made by a lion.
This is a deep threatening sound that animals make.
AT: "what Yahweh has solemnly said"
Babylon's enemies have overcome her. "Waves" represent many people groups overcoming Babylon. The words "sea" and "water" often represent the nations. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
AT: "Babylon's cities"
Bel was the main god of the Babylonians and represents the whole country and the people that worshiped it. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: out from his mouth what he swallowed
tn.text: Yahweh compares all the sacrifices and offering to Bel to things he ate. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: the nations will no longer flow
tn.text: Yahweh compares the many nations coming to Babylon to sacrifice to Bel to river that moves along.
The news that the people listen to. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The rulers represent the nations under their control. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
AT: "pay attention"
AT: "All of Babylon's people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Heaven and earth are viewed as if they were people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
AT: "what Yahweh has solemnly said"
AT: "the killed people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Jeremiah speaks to the Israelite people in verse 50.
AT: "hurtful, negative words"
to cry out because of pain or sadness
"her" refers to Babylon. This is a way of saying that it is impossible for Babylon to escape Yahweh's judgment.

tn.ref: A shout of distress came from Babylon, a great collapse from the land of the Chaldeans
tn.text: The same thought is expressed in two different ways for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: enemies roar like the waves of many waters
tn.text: The sound of the enemies coming will be very loud. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
This phrase can be changed to have an active verb. AT: "they captured her warriors." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
These refer to Babylon.
These are the names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: no man or animal will live in it
tn.text: These animals are those that are normally with people, because [[:en:bible:notes:jer:51:36|51:37]] states that Babylon will be inhabited by jackals or wild animals.
AT: "Babylon will disappear as this stone disappeared." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
